qas.question: What percentage of plant and animal species extinction is predicted in the 21st century?
What agreement has the Southeast Asian countries signed to combat haze pollution?
When did the 2 worst haze pollution occur in Southeast Asia?
What area is rich in trees and other Fauna?
What tiger is prospering despite deforistation?
Where were 40% of the animal and plant species destroyed already?

plausible_answers.text: "slash and burn" activities in Sumatra and Borneo

qas.question: What caused the 19th century reginal hazes?

context: While <b5_0><b7_0>Southeast Asia<b7_0/><b5_0/> is rich in flora and fauna, Southeast Asia is facing severe deforestation which causes habitat loss for various endangered species such as orangutan and the <b6_0>Sumatran tiger<b6_0/>. Predictions have been made that more than <a0_0>40%<a0_0/> of the animal and plant species in Southeast Asia could be wiped out in the 21st century. At the same time, haze has been a regular occurrence. The two worst regional hazes were in <a4_0>1997 and 2006<a4_0/> in which multiple countries were covered with thick haze, mostly <a2_0>caused by <b8_0>"slash and burn" activities<a2_0/> in <a1_0>Sumatra and Borneo<b8_0/><a1_0/>. In reaction, <b9_0>several countries in Southeast Asia<b9_0/> signed the ASEAN Agreement on <a3_0>Transboundary Haze Pollution<a3_0/> to combat haze pollution.
